summary: This document is an email chain from April 1, 2019, between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discussing the Epstein investigation. The emails focus on following up about the scanning and transmission of records (16,000 to 29,000 pages) to a colleague and confirming the creation of an index or catalog of the materials.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: The sender of an email on January 30, 2019, providing contact information and offering assistance regarding records information for the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Follow-up on records conversation
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney follows up on a conversation about Epstein investigation records, providing contact info and offering to set up another call.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

events.title: Check-in on scanned records transmission
events.description: A team member checks in to confirm the transmission of scanned records (16,000 to 29,000 pages) to a colleague and requests an index or catalog of the materials.

events.title: Follow-up on record upload
events.description: A follow-up email inquires if everything has been uploaded to the W drive, referencing a prior conversation.

events.title: Coordination on investigation follow-up
events.description: Email exchange about coordinating a 'one-two punch' to follow up on the Epstein investigation records matter.

keyFacts: The emails discuss the handling of a large volume of scanned records (16,000 to 29,000 pages) related to the Epstein investigation.
The correspondence indicates an ongoing effort within the U.S. Attorney's Office to catalog and manage evidence in the case.
Multiple follow-ups in January, February, March, and April 2019 show persistent coordination among team members on this records issue.
The document reflects internal prosecution team communications about evidence logistics, not substantive allegations or witness testimony.
